awd_titl_txt: Machine-Learning-Optimized Refractory Metasurfaces for Thermophotovoltaic Energy Conversion
awd_abstract_narration:
Nontechnical:

Developing new, environmentally friendly energy sources is one of the grand engineering challenges faced by society. Thermophotovoltaic devices convert waste heat into usable electricity and have attracted a great research interest to satify the increasing need for electrical power. Thermophotovoltaic (TPV) systems can take advantage of many energy sources, including solar energy and waste heat from fossil fuels and industrial processes. TPV systems could enable low-weight, versatile and compact electricity generators that are noiseless, low-maintenance and energy-efficient. Realizing high-efficiency TPV systems requires advancing fundamental knowledge of materials, photonics, and design. A key challenge is to optimize multi-functional TPV components and their constituent materials for stable operation under environment and extreme temperatures. This project will use artificial intelligenc (machine learning) to merge the knowledge of optical materials with advanced optimization to achieve highly efficient TPV systems. The project will create a fundamentally new, machine-learning-assisted optimization framework for the realization of advanced TPV components. This project will leverage the extended knowledge and database of tailorable optical materials and integrate machine-learning algorithms with photonic designs.

Technical:

In the recent years, there has been significant research interest in engineering the optical and spectral properties of materials through the use of photonic metasurfaces for efficient energy conversion, including thermophotovoltaics. The proposed program merges advanced photonic topology optimization with deep-learning-based inverse design methods and a comprehensive material database to unlock unorthodox optical designs for the realization of highly-efficient components for TPV applications. This effort will expand the design parameter space and incorporate machine-learning approaches to achieve the dramatic improvement of the speed and efficiency of topology optimization, as well as to build a large documented materials database. Through unconventional optical design, the program aims to develop highly efficient TPV energy conversion approaches by enhancing radiative heat transfer process. The proposed TPV device could enable unparalleled energy conversion efficiency potentially exceeding 50% by matching the emissivity of the emitter to the bandgap of commercial photovoltaic cells such as silicon, gallium antimonide, indium gallium arsenide. This approach could elevate nanophotonic designs into previously unavailable regimes and can be applied to photonic systems beyond TPV.

por.por_cntn:
Efficient thermophotovoltaic (TPV) systems are expected to play a crucial role in the sustainable economy of the future as these systems can convert heat into electricity. This is done via an intermediate process where a thermal emitter converts heat to thermal radiation, which is subsequently converted into electricity. These systems utilize refractory materials, which can physically withstand high temperatures, as well as remain chemically stable under extreme conditions. To further enhance the thermal and optical properties of the refractory thermal emitter, the concept of metasurfaces can be utilized. The principle of metasurfaces is artificially shaping materials on the nanoscale to engineer desired electromagnetic properties or enhance existing ones. This can be done via nanofabrication, utilizing processes similar to the semiconductor industry. Traditional metasurfaces utilize periodic designs of simple geometries (such as squares, rectangles, circles, etc.) to shape materials. However, these designs are inherently restricted in their performance as simple geometries often fail to capture the intricacies of material interaction with light and heat. Machine learning (ML) provides an optimization framework to tune the geometries of these metasurfaces to obtain superior performance compared to traditional geometries. It also enables the technique of inverse design, where we have a set of expected properties and we design the metasurface and the materials in a way that can achieve them.

In this project, we develop an inverse design technique based on optimization of the metasurface topology. This method produces engineered metasurface geometries which not only account for material fabrication imperfections, but also achieve the desired performance. However, optimization of topology is computationally intensive as the algorithm has to work through several types of geometrical designs from the training set and converge on a design that reaches the desired performance metrics. To tackle this, we also developed a ML-assisted technique involving an adversarial autoencoder mixed in with the topology optimization framework. Using this approach reduces the optimization time considerably by transforming a huge training set into a lower-dimensional "latent space", which includes crucial elements of the training set and serves as a method to optimize several parameters of interest simultaneously. To test the results of the ML-assisted inverse design, refractory materials were grown and optically characterized at high temperatures using ellipsometry and fabrication attempts were done to manufacture them.  

We also developed ML-driven generative model based on the emerging latent diffusion model to ensure robust inverse designed metasurfaces. Additionally, we also introduced physics-conditioned optimization framework embedding physical knowledge into the ML model, which enhances the accuracy of the design search in the latent space.

The project’s results have been reported in ten peer-reviewed publications, with additional papers nearing publication. Several graduate students were trained in ML optimization, material growth and nanofabrication. This work was presented at several conferences on machine learning, optics, and metamaterials by the graduate students and the PIs.
